lines.text:
[waiting for the plane to take off]
I have two enormous pills to steady me down and the two pep-pills I took this morning - the pep-up pills. I'm flying already!
I love you for what you are. Not what you think you are.

What a ridiculous form of locomotion flying is. They tie you to your chair and tell you you're going, then they make scarifying noises with their engines, then they untie you and tell you're not going at all. Can you imagine the Queen Mary behaving like that?
300 pounds a day. I can keep my home now.
Your plane, your grace.
Tell it, it can go without me.
Pay no attention. Drunks cry very easily. It's only the whiskey.

[They are playing cards, watched by a reporter]
Not that one. *That* one!
How do you know what is in my hand?
Because I know what is in your head.
So, I have nothing in my head.

[to the reporter]
Don't quote that.
Well, I give you something you can quote. From Tiempo, the movie critic, it said, Gloria Gritti is an actress who's talent is equal to her intelligence.
How unkind. Gin, I think.
"No" is not a word that I recognise.
You've recognised it for the past three months.
A hundred years ago, top people were top people because they were born top people, but you know something, love? A hundred years from now, top people will be top people because they deserve to be.
The line to Borghamn is temporarily out of order. Can somebody please tell me how it is possible for a telephone to be disordered by a fog?
Well, let's have another go at this.
[Grabs a bottle of champagne]
Well, I'll be squiffy!
Marvelous! That, I should like to see, Miss Mead. Just once. What am I talking about, just once? If I don't see it tonight, I don't suppose I ever will.
I know it is foolishly sentimental to want to sit next to the man that you are eloping with.
For most of those thirteen years I've loved him. But I don't know him.
You? Why should you be scared of him?
As a child I was scared of the dark.
That is what I love you for. That I can make fun of you.
Tell me, eh, with Room With No View, how much did we gross?
Oh, without Tokyo?
Yes.
You brought the agreements?
Yes.
With my Lichtenstein or my Hong Kong company?
A new one. The friendly Isles. No taxes at all!
No taxes? Ha-ha-ha. My darling, Dr. Schwartzbacher!
Is everything in order?
Eh, well not all together, I'm afraid.
Your grace is traveling on Flight 905 to Miami.
The, Duchess of Brighton, oh yes, it's under D. Ha-ha. Would that be it?

[to Sanders]
He does mix his tenses, though, would it, was it. It is.
Why do I have to travel with this ridiculous bag. It's like a bottomless pit. Oh! You know, I'm sure I had it when I left home.
Yes, but I'm afraid you can't travel to America without a vaccination certificate, madame.
Why not? I once came through an epidemic of black water fever in Uganda and I hadn't been inoculated or anything? I'm really not afraid of a little small pox.
Yes, well I'm afraid its a regulation, madame.
It's a very idiotic one.

The truth is, I'm a little strung out. You see, its the first time I've ever flown. And this morning I had to borrow one of my maid Armstrong's pep-up pills. Ha. It pepped me up, alright, but, not just up, but in all directions, it seems.
Ladies and Gentlemen, would you kindly fasten your seat belts, please.
I haven't brought a seat belt with me.
You must be sitting on it.
Oh, well, have you got one?
Yes, I have.
Oh, I see. What happens now?
You should have another part.
Oh, here it is...
Here, there we are. Here, this way.
I'll leave it to you.
Now, you put that through there. That, that through there and you're fastened to your chair.
You can't be expected to know that. What are they going to do? Loop-the-loop, or something?
This is a problem, darling. How am I going to fix adjoining rooms for us, without seeming too obvious?
Your past experience, should help you there, shouldn't it?
Have I married, a Cat?
You haven't married anything yet?
Where do you want to go, Marc?
What do you mean?
Cannes is a bit dead in January. What about the West Indies? No, of course, you'd miss your gambling, wouldn't you. What about Rio? That's pleasant at this time of year.
I'm going to New York, Paul. With your wife.
I made this out for 10,000 pounds. That's at least twice your nuisance value. But, I don't enjoy haggling.
That word seems to have stuck in your throat, a bit.
Gigolo or aging?
Not aging, we're all aging.
But, yes, gigolo does hurt. I suppose because its kind of true. I have made love to women for, oh, not for money, really, really not for money, or for what I could get out of it, but, well,
Well?
For fun! It's true. I'm just one of nature's lay-abouts, I suppose.
I love you very deeply, you know.
Good. You haven't told me why?
You so much want looking after. And I so much want to look after you.
Darling, I simply have to get out of this dress and take a bath.
What happened? You got lost in the fog?
Oh well, ha-ha, here's to better days.
Better days.
Mr, Mr, Andros? I-I don't suppose you've ever before been approached by a perfectly strange woman in a hotel lounge asking you for 153,750 pounds?
No, I, don't think I have.

[Talking on the phone]
No, I want to speak to Dawkins.

[Walks into the Director's office]
Excuse me, sir.
Shhh!
[Talking on the phone]

Dawkins? Airport Director, here. I want the royal lounge made ready by 10 hundred hours for the Russian delegation. Oh, about 20 of them, I think. Lay out caviar, champagne and cake. Oh, some kind of Russian-looking cake. Well, how should I know what makes a cake look Russian! Use your imagination, Dawkins.
May I speak to you sir? Its extremely urgent.
45, the lounge must be ready for the American delegation. Oh, sandwiches, coffee and bourbon. Their take-off is 11 hundred hours.
[Hangs up phone]
Yes, what is it?
It's my VIP list, sir. I thought perhaps you might know who Mr. Len Mason is?
Why should I? Your VIPs, your own pigeon, Sanders. I've got my own to look after. And they're a great deal more important than your film stars and oil magnets!
